0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-ryan-idUSKCN0Z326V	Ryan says Republicans should follow 'conscience' on Trump	"
WASHINGTON Republican lawmakers should follow their conscience on whether to support Donald Trump in November's presidential election
column2: U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan has said in an interview
column3: reflecting the party's unease over its White House candidate. ""The last thing I would do is tell anybody to do something that's contrary to their conscience. Of course I wouldn't do that
column4: the Republicans' most senior elected official said in excerpts released on Friday of an NBC interview set to air on Sunday. Some Republican leaders and lawmakers in the House of Representatives are struggling to get behind the New York businessman
column5: who last month became the party's presumptive nominee for the Nov. 8 election.After an initial delay
column6: Ryan has said he will back Trump but he has also acknowledged deep differences with him. He denounced as textbook racism Trump's criticism of a Mexican-American judge and has also criticized Trump's proposal - reiterated after the  massacre of 49 people in a gay bar in Orlando on Sunday - to temporarily bar Muslims from the United States.As Republicans seek to keep control of both chambers of Congress
column7: Trump's comments on such issues have also worried some lawmakers concerned about their own election prospects
column8: particularly in close races. All 247 House Republican seats are up for grabs in the election.

column1: Trump
column2: who has welcomed support from Ryan
column3: this week fired back at Republican leaders
column4: telling them to stop speaking out against him or else risk him potentially running ""by myself.""Ryan said earlier this week at his weekly press conference that he does not plan to withdraw his support of Trump
column5: although they disagree on some key issues.

column1: I feel as a responsibility institutionally as the speaker of the House that I should not be leading some chasm in the middle of our party. Because you know what I know that'll do? That'll definitely knock us out of the White House
column2: Ryan said in the interview for NBC's ""Meet the Press"" program.Trump's embrace this week of the lesbian
column3: gay
column4: bisexual and transgender community and potential gun control measures
column5: in contrast to general Republican orthodoxy have also thrown conservative lawmakers.

column1: Still
column2: Republican leaders have to reconcile their unease with the fact that primary Republican voters opted for Trump. He has never held elected office before but won more than enough delegates to secure the party's nomination at the Republican convention in July.  (Writing by Susan Heavey; Additional reporting by Meg Garner; Editing by Frances Kerry)"	['Paul'

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-iran-transportation-boeing-congress-idUSKCN0Z320T	Potential Boeing Iran sale faces opposition in U.S. Congress	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Two senior Republican House of Representatives lawmakers said on Friday they were concerned that Boeing Co's reported plans to sell aircraft to Iran could threaten U.S. national security and had requested more information from the company.""American companies should not be complicit in weaponizing the Iranian Regime
column2: Representatives Jeb Hensarling and Peter Roskam said in a letter to Boeing released on Friday.Iran said on Tuesday it had reached an agreement with Boeing for the supply of jetliners
column3: reopening the country's skies to new U.S. aircraft for the first time in decades under an international nuclear agreement that eased sanctions.Boeing has not confirmed an aircraft sale agreement.The company on Tuesday declined to provide detailed comment in response to Western and Middle East sources saying Iran had reached an understanding with the company to acquire over 100 passenger jets.

column1: The nuclear pact reached by Democratic President Barack Obama was opposed by every Republican member of the U.S. Congress. Several questioned the Boeing deal as soon as the news reports came out.In their letter to Boeing Chief Executive Dennis Muilenburg
column2: the lawmakers asked for ""clarification"" of the current state of negotiations.

column1: Their questions included whether Boeing could guarantee that Iran's government could not convert Boeing passenger aircraft to cargo aircraft and whether it would repossess aircraft if Iran violated the nuclear agreement.Hensarling is chairman of the House Financial Services Committee and Roskam is chairman of the Oversight subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee.Not every congressional Republican is opposed to a potential U.S. aircraft deal.
Senator Mark Kirk
column2: who represents Illinois
column3: where Boeing is headquartered
column4: said in a hallway interview at the Senate he had mixed feelings about it.""You want the jobs
column5: but you are worried about what the Iranians are going to do with the aircraft
column6: Kirk said this week. (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Richard Chang)"	['Kirk'

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-rubio-idUSKCN0Z31L2	Florida lawmaker drops Senate bid to make way for Rubio	"
U.S. Representative David Jolly ended his bid for a U.S. Senate seat from Florida on Friday
column2: opening the way for Marco Rubio to seek re-election in an effort to help Republicans maintain control of the chamber.""Marco is saying he's getting in
column3: Jolly
column4: a fellow Republican who has been running to fill the seat for the past 10 months
column5: said on CNN. Rubio dropped out of the race for the Republican presidential nomination. Later Friday
column6: Jolly
column7: who represents the area around St. Petersburg and Clearwater
column8: said he will run for re-election to his congressional seat.""Today I am asking my friends and neighbors to let me continue doing my job as a member of Congress
column9: Jolly said in a news conference in Clearwater.He will likely face former Governor Charlie Crist

column1: Rubio
column2: who ended his presidential bid in March
column3: said this week he was reconsidering running and may decide as early as this weekend. Representatives for Rubio declined to answer questions about his future plans.At the news conference
column4: Jolly said he fully expects Rubio to run for re-election to the Senate. His spokesman Preston Rudie told Reuters the congressman ""had no actual knowledge of a Rubio decision.""

column1: Rubio's entry into the senate race would complicate Democrats' efforts to win back a majority in the Senate in the November election.Republicans won control of the Senate in the 2014 mid-term election and now hold 54 seats in the 100-seat chamber. Democrats have 44 seats and two independents are aligned with them.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and other Republicans have urged Rubio to run despite a pledge during his presidential campaign not to seek re-election. They cited polls showing he is the only Republican who can win the state.The deadline is June 24 for candidates to file with Florida election officials their intention to run for the Senate. The Republican primary election will be held on Aug. 30. (Reporting by Kouichi Shirayanagi and Richard Cowan; Editing by Susan Heavey and Jeffrey Benkoe)"	['Rubio'

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-sanders-idUSKCN0Z305E	Sanders vows to help Clinton beat Trump
column2: but keeps campaign alive	"

column1: By John Whitesides
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Bernie Sanders promised on Thursday to work with presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton to defeat Republican Donald Trump in the Nov. 8 election
column2: but did not formally pull out of the race for the White House.Sanders did not endorse Clinton during an online speech to his supporters
column3: but made it clear he was shifting his focus to building a grassroots movement to fight for his liberal policy agenda and transform the Democratic Party.""The major political task that we face in the next five months is to make certain that Donald Trump is defeated and defeated badly
column4: and I personally intend to begin my role in that process in a very short period of time
column5: the U.S. senator from Vermont said.""I also look forward to working with Secretary Clinton to transform the Democratic Party so that it becomes a party of working people and young people
column6: and not just wealthy campaign contributors
column7: he said in a speech broadcast from his hometown of Burlington
column8: Vermont.

column1: Sanders
column2: who has resisted pressure from Democrats to exit the White House race and back Clinton since she clinched the party nomination last week
column3: said he would keep fighting for his goals of reducing income inequality
column4: removing big money from politics and reining in Wall Street.""Defeating Donald Trump cannot be our only goal. We must continue our grassroots efforts to create the America that we know we can become
column5: he said. ""And we must take that energy into the Democratic National Convention on July 25 in Philadelphia where we will have more than 1
column6: 900 delegates.""

column1: Sanders has kept his campaign alive as leverage to force concessions from Clinton on his policy goals during deliberations on the party's issues platform
column2: and on the reforms he seeks in the Democratic Party's nominating process.But he has laid off some staff
column3: stopped campaigning and dropped plans to court unbound delegates in an unspoken acknowledgment the former secretary of state will be the nominee.

column1: Sanders
column2: who met with Clinton on Tuesday night after the nominating process ended
column3: said he would continue his discussions with her campaign to make certain ""the Democratic Party passes the most progressive platform in its history
column4: and that Democrats actually fight for that agenda.""""Our vision for the future of this country is not some kind of fringe idea. It is not a radical idea. It is mainstream. It is what millions of Americans believe in and want to see happen
column5: Sanders said. (Editing by Peter Cooney)"	['Sanders'

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-guns-idUSKCN0Z21HX	Senate inches toward possible gun control action	"
By Susan Cornwell and Richard Cowan
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON A long-running battle over gun control in the United States reaches a critical stage next week in the U.S. Senate amid signs Americans are more willing to accept limited restrictions after the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history.While it is far from likely new measures will pass
column2: the Orlando
column3: Florida
column4: gay nightclub massacre of 49 people and a suggestion by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump that something be done have fostered a different atmosphere.While President Barack Obama was in Orlando consoling the survivors of the rampage by a gunman who claimed allegiance to Islamic State militants
column5: the U.S. Senate moved closer to votes on limited gun control measures.About 71 percent of Americans
column6: including eight out of 10 Democrats and nearly six out of 10 Republicans
column7: favor at least moderate regulations and restrictions on guns
column8: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll conducted from Monday to Thursday. That was up from 60 percent in late 2013 and late 2014.As always
column9: Democrats were challenging Republicans to vote for new restrictions and reject pressure from the National Rifle Association
column10: the powerful gun lobby that has been known to punish politicians who thwart its will.U.S. Senator Chris Murphy of Connecticut and fellow Democrats set the U.S. Capitol abuzz by talking on the Senate floor for nearly 15 straight hours to demand that Congress act on gun control.They ended their speeches before dawn
column11: citing a Republican pledge to hold votes soon on measures to expand background checks on gun buyers and to prevent people on U.S. terrorism watch lists from buying guns.VOTES ON MONDAY

column1: The Senate is expected to vote on Monday on four proposals. One from Democrat Dianne Feinstein would let the government prevent terrorist suspects from buying guns. A second from Republican John Cornyn
column2: the No. 2 Senate Republican
column3: would require court approval within three days for a government ban on an individual's attempt to buy a gun. Democrats have said Cornyn's plan is unworkable; Republicans say Feinstein's might harm the rights of people wrongly on terror suspect lists.

column1: A third proposal
column2: from Democrat Murphy
column3: would expand background check procedures to the sales of all firearms
column4: including those online and at gun shows. A fourth proposal
column5: from Republican Senator Chuck Grassley
column6: would provide for law enforcement to be notified if a person investigated for terrorism in the last five years tries to buy a gun. Gun control is a potent issue in U.S. politics. Republicans
column7: who control the Senate
column8: have blocked Democratic-backed gun control measures over the years
column9: saying they infringe on the right to bear arms guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution.Any bill would have to pass both houses of Congress and be signed by the president to become law. At his weekly news conference on Thursday
column11: speaker of the House of Representatives
column12: injected a note of caution.""We don't take away a citizen's rights without due process
column14: the top U.S. elected Republican. ""If you have a quick idea in the heat of the moment that says let's take away a person's rights without due process
column15: we're going to defend the Constitution.""

column1: MASS SHOOTINGS
A string of mass shootings across the United States in schoolhouses
column2: churches
column3: movie theaters and other public places has failed to break the deadlock.The last major gun control measure was a ban in 1994 on semi-automatic assault weapons such as the one used in Orlando on Sunday. The ban expired 10 years later.One of the most dramatic moments in the Senate debate came when Republican Senator John McCain
column4: who is in a tough re-election race in Arizona
column5: told reporters Obama is ""directly responsible"" for Islamic State-inspired attacks on Americans like the one in Orlando.He later said he meant to say he blamed Obama's decision to withdraw most U.S. forces from Iraq
column6: and that this had fueled the rise of Islamic State.

column1: Murphy
column2: asked what would be the message if the Senate fails to act on the gun control measures next week
column3: suggested it could be a campaign issue for the Nov. 8 election.""There are going to be a lot of voters in this country who are going to watch ... the votes that are cast next week
column4: he said.TALKING TO NRA

column1: Trump
column2: the presumptive Republican nominee for president has been endorsed by the NRA. He jumped into the gun debate by saying he would meet with NRA leaders to talk about barring people who are on terrorism watch lists from buying guns.""I'll be looking at it very
column3: very seriously - the terror watch list and the no-fly list
column4: I'm going to be talking to the NRA about that and starting a real dialogue. I think a lot of people agree with me but I want to really hear what they have to say
column5: Trump told Fox News on Wednesday night.Democrats were deeply skeptical that Trump's word signaled any sort of shift toward more Republican support for Democratic-backed gun control proposals.""He is going to meet with the NRA. ... What's he going to come out saying? 'Oh the NRA and I agreed we shouldn't have terrorists have guns
column6: ' but doing nothing about it
column7: U.S. Senator Chuck Schumer of New York told reporters.  (Additional reporting by Alana Wise and Mohammad Zargham; Writing by Steve Holland; Editing by Howard Goller and Peter Cooney)"	['Feinstein'
column8: 'Paul'

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-republicans-idUSKCN0Z22MU	Trumped by candidate's rhetoric
column2: Republican lawmakers at a loss for words	"

column1: By David Morgan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The awkward efforts of Republicans to embrace their party's standard-bearer Donald Trump looked particularly painful in Congress this week as lawmakers ducked into elevators
column2: dashed away from reporters
column3: ignored questions or
column4: worse
column5: tried to answer them. Only days after a furor over his criticism of a Mexican-American judge
column6: the presumptive presidential nominee sent Republicans reeling again by renewing his call for a ban on Muslim immigration after a gunman who pledged allegiance to Islamic militants killed of 49 people at a Florida nightclub.Then former reality TV star Trump waded into two sensitive topics for social conservatives by embracing the lesbian
column7: gay
column8: bisexual and transgender (LGBT) community and suggesting the country may need certain new gun control measures.  For lawmakers accustomed to well-crafted talking points and predictable lines of questioning
column9: the week marked a chaotic flurry of contorted responses or terse
column10: tight-lipped replies.Senator John Barrasso of Wyoming walked away when asked about Trump's embrace of the LGBT community
column11: saying: ""I don't know what the latest is. I haven't read anything. I haven't been watching.""Florida Senator Marco Rubio
column12: a former Trump adversary in the presidential primaries
column13: had to bat away two Trump questions before he could announce that he is considering running for re-election - a decision that could determine whether Republicans retain control of the Senate in the Nov. 8 election.Senator Ted Cruz
column15: refused to respond directly to the speech in which Trump hardened his line on Muslims while Senate Intelligence Chairman Richard Burr called it ""an OK speech"" before stepping into an elevator and refusing to respond to any more questions.

column1: The Trump challenge is obvious even for seasoned Republicans.         ""I'm spending my days commenting on everything that Donald Trump says
column2: lamented John McCain
column3: chairman of Senate Armed Services Committee.Orrin Hatch
column4: the longest-serving Republican in the Senate
column5: ricocheted from rejection of Trump's comments on Muslims to doubts about the legality of his proposed immigration ban to bafflement over the billionaire's response to the Orlando shootings.

column1: 'YOU CAN'T MAKE THIS UP'
Trump controversies have also overshadowed House Speaker Paul Ryan's rollout of a policy agenda
column2: a campaign document that was supposed to help bring Trump's position more into line with mainline party doctrine. Asked on Thursday whether he was bothered by having to contend with Trump's remarks
column3: Ryan called Trump ""a different kind of candidate...(in) a different kind of year.""

column1: Asked how many more times he would be called on to do so
column2: Ryan said: ""I don't know the answer to that question either.""In an ironic message to his critics among the Republican leadership this week
column3: Trump had this to say: ""Be quiet
column4: just please be quiet. Don't talk. Please be quiet. Just be quiet.""Ryan's response? ""...You can't make this up sometimes
column5: he said.  A political neophyte who has never held elected office
column6: Trump has also said he may not need much from his Republican colleagues on Capitol Hill anyway.""We have to have our Republicans either stick together or let me just do it by myself. I'll do very well
column7: he said in a CNN interview. ""A lot of people thought I should do that anyway
column8: but I'll just do it very nicely by myself.""    (Reporting by David Morgan; additional reporting by Richard Cowan
column9: Susan Cornwell and Alana Wise; Editing by Cynthia Osterman)"	['Barrasso'

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-mccain-idUSKCN0Z22OG	McCain says he 'misspoke' in blaming Obama for attacks on Americans	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON U.S. Senator John McCain said on Thursday that President Barack Obama was ""directly responsible"" for attacks on Americans like the one in Florida because of policies that contributed to the rise of the Islamic State. But the Arizona Republican later  said he misspoke.McCain
column2: who is in a tough re-election race
column3: made the comments after reporters chased him down a marble stairway and into a hallway of the U.S. Capitol. They asked what he was hearing from constituents about gun control issues being debated in the Senate after Sunday's shooting rampage by a gunman who claimed allegiance to Islamic State militants.""I'm hearing a lot from my constituents about what happened and of course I am making them realize that Barack Obama is directly responsible for it
column4: McCain said.""Because when he pulled everybody out of Iraq
column5: al Qaeda went to Syria
column6: became ISIS
column7: and ISIS is what it is today thanks to Barack Obama's failures
column8: utter failures
column9: McCain said. ""So the responsibility for it lies with President Barack Obama and his failed policies.""

column1: After media reports began to appear about his comments
column2: McCain
column3: who lost the White House to Obama in the 2008 presidential election
column4: posted a clarification on Twitter and then issued a statement that said he meant to blame Obama's policies
column5: not the president personally.""I misspoke. I did not mean to imply that the president was personally responsible. I was referring to President Obama's national security decisions
column6: not the president himself
column7: McCain said in the statement.Forty-nine people died in the shooting in Orlando
column8: the worst mass shooting in modern U.S. history. The gunman was U.S.-born Omar Mateen

column1: McCain
column3: faces multiple opponents in a Republican primary race in August
column4: and some analysts say he is in danger of losing the Senate seat he has held for three decades.Earlier this week
column5: presumptive Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump appeared to suggest Obama may have been complicit in the Orlando attacks.

column1: Look
column2: we're led by a man that either is not tough
column3: not smart
column4: or he's got something else in mind
column5: Trump told Fox News. ""And the something else in mind -- you know
column6: people can't believe it ... There's something going on. It's inconceivable. There's something going on."" (Editing by Doina Chiacu and Tom Brown)"	['McCain'

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-usa-refugees-idUSKCN0Z22R4	White House sees surge in Syrian refugee admissions this year	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The Obama administration believes it will be able to process many more Syrian refugees in the last half of fiscal 2016 than in the first six months
column2: allowing it to meet its goal of admitting at least 10
column3: 000 by Sept. 30.In a letter to Democratic Senator Richard Durbin seen by Reuters on Thursday
column4: the White House said it has allocated additional staff and added more processing locations in the Middle East to expedite the screening process without compromising U.S. security.""Therefore
column5: we expect to admit more Syrians in the third and fourth quarters of fiscal year 2016 than we did in the first and second quarters to meet our goal of admitting at least 10
column6: 000 Syrian refugees this fiscal year
column7: the letter said.The administration's move is in sharp contrast to recent anti-refugee rhetoric by many Republicans
column8: especially since the killings in Orlando on Sunday raised fears of attacks.Donald Trump
column10: has called for the refugee resettlement program to be suspended
column11: saying ""We don't know who they are. They have no documentation
column12: and we don't know what they're planning.""

column1: Backers of the administration's plan dispute such statements
column2: citing the extensive screening process the Syrian refugees undergo.So far
column3: the United States has offered refuge to far fewer of the millions fleeing the war in Syria than many of its closest allies. Germany has taken in hundreds of thousands and Canada admitted nearly 30
column4: 000 between November 2015 and May 1

column1: The letter said the administration had set up a temporary processing center in Jordan and expanded operations in Turkey. It also has restarted interviews in neighboring Lebanon
column2: and begun limited processing in Erbil
column3: Iraq.Durbin was a lead author of a letter to President Barack Obama in May
column4: which was signed by more than half the Democrats in the Senate and urged the president to move more quickly to admit Syrians.By mid-May
column5: only 1
column6: 736 Syrians had been allowed into the country
column7: a pace that would have fallen far short of the 10
column8: 000 goal for the full year.

column1: The letter seen on Thursday was the administration's response to the one sent in May.Obama's plan to admit 10
column2: 000 Syrians was met with a firestorm of criticism in the United States
column3: mostly from Republicans who say that violent militants could enter the country by posing as refugees. More than 30 governors
column4: most of them Republicans
column5: have tried to keep refugees out of their states. (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by John Walcott and Sandra Maler)"	['Jordan'
column6: 'Durbin'
column7: 'Obama']	[]

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-illinois-bonds-idUSKCN0Z22HK	Illinois budget impasse hits $550 million bond sale	"
By Karen Pierog and Dave McKinney
| CHICAGO

CHICAGO Illinois' long-running budget impasse stung the state on Thursday in the U.S. municipal market where buyers of its $550 million bond issue demanded bigger yields over the market benchmark.The pricing was ""surprisingly soft
column2: considering a strong rally in muni bonds on Thursday
column3: said Greg Saulnier
column4: a Municipal Market Data analyst. The results demonstrate that the market is increasing its penalty due to the state's worsening fiscal and political problems
column5: leaving Illinois unable to take full advantage of the historically low borrowing rates.Bank of America Merrill Lynch won the tax-exempt general obligation deal in competitive bidding
column6: pricing bonds due in 2026 with a 5 percent coupon to yield 3.32 percent
column7: which is 185 basis points over MMD's triple-A yield scale. The spread was 175 basis points ahead of the bond sale
column8: according to MMD
column9: a unit of Thomson Reuters. It was also wider than the 154 basis-point spread in 10 years for Illinois' $480 million GO bond sale in January.Illinois is poised to be the only U.S. state since at least the 1930s to end a fiscal year without a complete budget.Its Republican governor and Democratic-controlled legislature have so far failed to reach a deal on fiscal 2016 or 2017 spending plans. That leaves unaddressed the growing structural budget deficit and huge $111 billion unfunded pension liability in the fifth-biggest U.S. state.The bond issue itself was seen as a weapon in the political war to pressure Democrats to cave in to Governor Bruce Rauner's demands
column10: while losing money for the cash-strapped state.

column1: ILLINOIS SELLS INTO MARKET RALLY
Muni yields have been hitting new record lows on MMD's scale in recent days
column2: driven by cash-heavy investors chasing low supply of debt.Rauner's office said the true interest cost for the bonds
column3: which carry maturities from 2017 to 2041
column4: was 3.74 percent
column5: down from 3.99 percent in the January sale
column6: and the lowest ever for similar general obligation bonds issued by the state.

column1: It's clear from today's bond sale that investors realize Illinois now has a governor that is trying to turn the state around and right its fiscal ship
column2: Rauner spokeswoman Catherine Kelly said in a statement.Some market participants thought Illinois' so-called credit spread should be even wider.""It's odd to me
column3: said Nicholos Venditti
column4: a portfolio manager at Thornburg Investment Management. ""Illinois has proven time and time again they can't get anything done.""   Heading into the deal
column5: Illinois' credit ratings
column6: which were already the lowest among the states
column7: were downgraded by Moody's Investor Service and Standard & Poor's.

column1: The governor's office also revealed on Wednesday that the state lacks appropriations to actually spend all the proceeds earmarked mainly for road construction and mass transit projects due to the impasse.State Treasurer Michael Frerichs
column2: a first-term Democrat
column3: predicted the bond issue could be a net money-loser for Illinois if the borrowed funds go unspent and must be invested short-term.""We'll make far less in interest than we'll be paying in interest to the bondholders
column4: Frerichs said in an interview. ""I think we need to make these investments in infrastructure
column5: but we're going about it in the wrong order. It seems backwards issuing the bonds and hoping they get an appropriation to spend them.""On Wednesday
column6: Rauner administration officials warned of the imminent shutdown of transportation projects and the loss of 25
column7: 000 construction jobs without a budget deal.Spokesmen for House Speaker Michael Madigan and Senate President John Cullerton
column8: both Democrats
column9: declined to speculate on the chances of either legislative chamber granting the Rauner administration the spending authority it needs to fully tap the bond issue.  (Editing by Daniel Bases and Matthew Lewis)"	['Rauner'

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-beverages-philadelphia-sodatax-idUSKCN0Z22G3	Philadelphia passes soda tax after mayor rewrites playbook	"
By Luc Cohen
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Philadelphia Mayor Jim Kenney scored a victory that had eluded more than 40 U.S. public officials who took on the powerful U.S. soda industry when the city council voted on Thursday to slap a tax on sweetened drinks. After a bitter
column2: months-long battle
column3: the city council voted 13-4 to approve a 1.5 cent-per-ounce tax on sugary and diet drinks beginning in January. The council already approved the plan in a preliminary vote last week
column4: and the outcome had not been expected to change. The City of Brotherly Love became the biggest U.S. city to have such a tax. Much smaller Berkeley
column5: California
column6: was the first.Similar efforts
column7: including several spearheaded by former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg
column8: were defeated after intense lobbying from organizations like the American Beverage Association
column9: which opposes the Philadelphia move and represents Coca-Cola Co and PepsiCo Inc. Following Thursday's vote
column10: the ABA said it would take legal action to stop the tax. The Philadelphia vote marked a major victory for health advocates who say sugary drinks cause obesity and diabetes. But experts noted those concerns were not the focus for Kenney and other backers of the tax as they took on critics complaining that ""nanny state"" public health measures intrude on residents' personal lives.Instead
column11: Kenney rewrote the soda-tax advocate's playbook. He played up the benefits of the cash injection from the tax for the city's depleted coffers. In the first year
column12: the tax is projected to raise $91 million
column13: and he pledged to spend funds on public programs such as universal pre-kindergarten.""If you want to tax something and people know where the money's going to go
column14: then it's easier for them to get behind it
column15: Kenney said in an interview. He noted that focusing on revenue
column17: was largely responsible for the measure's passage. The strategic shift could lend momentum to movements in San Francisco
column21: Colorado. Residents of those cities will vote in November on similar taxes
column22: which could deal further blows to a U.S. soft drink industry already hit by declining soda consumption.U.S. soda consumption fell for the 11th straight year in 2015

column1: AVOIDING THE BLOOMBERG TRAP
Bloomberg made public health a centerpiece of his tenure as New York City mayor between 2002 and 2013. He moved to limit smoking in parks and restaurants
column2: ban transfats and require calorie counts posted in some restaurants.On soda
column3: he pushed for a tax
column4: then a ban on soda purchases with food stamps
column5: and finally a much-lampooned limit on the size of sugary drinks. His efforts were ultimately rejected
column6: with critics decrying the moves toward a ""nanny state."" The strategy worked in Britain
column7: where a new soft drinks levy was announced in March after officials emphasized the country's obesity crisis
column8: saying it cost the economy billions of pounds annually and was a huge burden on the state-funded health system.

column1: That approach never worked in Philadelphia. Michael Nutter
column2: the previous mayor
column3: twice tried to pass a soda tax as a health initiative and as a way to plug a budget shortfall. He was unable to push it through the city council.""Twice before it was used in Philadelphia and it was not successful. It was used in New York and it was not effective
column4: said Kenney
column5: adding that while the health benefits of a tax are not ""less important
column6: they are less tangible. Kenney
column7: who became mayor in January
column8: had made a campaign pledge to provide universal pre-kindergarten
column9: and he kept that issue as his focus. A spokeswoman said complex state laws on taxation made enacting a citywide soda tax the best option to raise revenue for that signature proposal.Bloomberg personally contributed funding to support Philadelphia's pro-tax campaigners.

column1: FIZZING WESTWARD

Opponents of Philadelphia's soda tax argued that the measure will disproportionately hurt the poor and prompt Philadelphians to travel to nearby suburbs to buy soda. A spokesman for No Philly Grocery Tax
column2: a local ABA-funded group
column3: said it would sue the city to stop it from imposing the ""unconstitutional"" tax
column4: but was still analyzing all its legal options. In a statement
